title: Nationwide exec retiring after 40 years with company
text: Nationwide exec retiring after 40 years with company Feb 21, 2017, 11:56am EST Industries & Tags Evan Weese Staff reporter Columbus Business First Share Evan Weese Staff reporter Columbus Business First Related Content Mark Pizzi, president of Nationwide's direct and member solutions channel, will retire… more Laura Sauer A longtime executive of Nationwide Mutual Insurance Co. is stepping down at year's end. The Columbus insurer said Mark Pizzi will retire after 40 years with the company, most recently as president of its direct and member solutions channel, overseeing the business unit selling directly to consumers rather than through agents. Mark Pizzi, president of Nationwide's direct and member solutions channel, will retire… more Laura Sauer Nationwide said Pizzi will assist in a transition that will see most of the direct and member solutions channel report to Mark Berven , the president and chief operating officer of Nationwide’s property and casualty organization. Pizzi’s position will be eliminated. “Mark’s pending retirement, and our ongoing strategy, provided an opportunity to examine how we’re organized,” spokesman Joe Case said in an email. In addition to assisting with the transition, Pizzi will continue to oversee Nationwide Bank, part of the company’s direct sales channel. Nationwide Bank recently named a new president . Pizzi joined Nationwide in 1978 as a personal lines underwriter in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania. He held a variety of field, staff, operational and leadership positions over his career, Nationwide said. Pizzi has been in his current role since 2014. “It has been an incredible privilege, both personally and professionally, to work with Mark," Nationwide CEO Steve Rasmussen said in a press release. "His vast knowledge of the business has helped Nationwide grow and be successful while his engaging leadership style has enabled him to build a strong team in every job he has held." Nationwide is a Fortune 100 company, with total sales of $43 billion in 2015, the latest year for which results are available. Evan Weese covers real estate, money and the business of sports for Columbus Business First. Related Content
